Powdery Shield Lichen

Physcia millegrana

Dusted in Light and Air

Tiny gray foliose rosettes that seem to bloom like frost across twigs and bark.

Powdery Shield Lichen is one of Minnesota’s most common small foliose lichens, recognized by its soft, powder-dusted surface and compact growth form. Its fine soredia give the thallus a matte, frosted look that distinguishes it from darker, more textured Physcia relatives.

E21A8057 Candleflame with Powdery Shield and Mealy Shadow
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/13.0 • Shutter 5 s
E21A8057 • Size: 2208x1472

The tiny foliose clusters of Powdery Shield (Physcia millegrana) form a fine, powder-dusted mat along the twig, each lobe coated with granular soredia. Below, a vivid patch of Candleflame (Candelaria concolor) adds a contrasting burst of yellow, together revealing how small-scale bark textures support mixed microcommunities of foliose and squamulose lichens.

Powdery Shield and Candleflame
Dust-gray rosettes rising above a bright cushion of Candleflame on a red maple twig.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 400 • Aperture f/5.6 • Shutter 1/250 s
E21A1081 • Size: 5112×3410

This mixed lichen community includes the bright lobes of Candleflame, the pale gray clusters of Powdery Shield, and the darker, granular rosettes of Mealy Shadow (Phaeophyscia orbicularis), with a small fragment of Common Greenshield appearing in the upper-left margin.

Candleflame and Powdery Shield on Elm Bark
A multi-species bark mosaic built from warm and cool tones.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/9.0 • Shutter 2.5 s
E21A8051–8055

Description

Powdery Shield Lichen is a small, pale gray foliose species with a characteristic matte, dusted surface.
This look comes from abundant soredia, tiny powder-like reproductive granules that spread easily across bark.

It forms small, loosely organized rosettes or diffuse patches, often blending into the bark more subtly than brighter species like Candleflame or Sunburst.

Typical companions on Minnesota hardwoods include:

  • Candleflame (Candelaria concolor)
  • Mealy Shadow (Phaeophyscia orbicularis)
  • Star Rosette (Physcia stellaris)
  • Common Greenshield (Flavoparmelia caperata)

Powdery Shield is an air-quality indicator, thriving in areas with clean, well-circulated air.

Identification

Key Features

  • Color: Pale gray, blue-gray, or slightly olive
  • Surface: Frosted or powder-dusted appearance from abundant soredia
  • Lobes: Extremely small (0.2–1.0 mm), rounded, tightly overlapping
  • Reproduction: Apothecia rare or absent — dispersal is primarily by soredia
  • Underside: Pale, with short, simple rhizines; edges often slightly uplifted
  • Growth Form: Small foliose rosettes or irregular patches, often intermixing with other bark lichens

Powdery Shield Lichen (Physcia millegrana) forms dense, pale gray foliose patches composed of very small, irregularly branched lobes. Its defining characteristic is the presence of abundant powdery soredia across the upper surface and margins, creating a frosted or dusted appearance that is visible even at a modest viewing distance.

Two close-scale images illustrate these diagnostic traits:

Soralia & Lobe Detail — Powdery Shield
Fine, powdery soredia coat the upper surface of *Physcia millegrana*, giving the thallus its frosted texture. A single upturned lobe reveals a pale underside—lighter than the neighboring Mealy Shadow—confirming foliose attachment and the species’ tightly clustered growth form.
E21A8057A • Size: 806×1209

Lobe Architecture — Powdery Shield
Tightly packed, minute lobes form a compact foliose mat, their pale gray surfaces contrasting with the darker bark beneath. Slight uplift along the lobe margins hints at the pale underside typical of *P. millegrana*, while the dense, irregular branching differentiates it from larger foliose Physcia species or nearby Mealy Shadow patches.
E21A8057B • Size: 541×811

Together, these views show the two most important diagnostic features:
(1) abundant soredia frosting the thallus, and
(2) tiny, densely overlapping lobes with a pale underside, distinguishing P. millegrana from species such as Hammered Shield (Punctelia rudecta) or Mealy Shadow (Physcia aipolia).

Distinguishing Powdery Shield from Similar Species

  • vs. Mealy Shadow (Phaeophyscia orbicularis)
    • Mealy Shadow is darker, more granular, with more defined rosettes.
    • Powdery Shield is lighter and more uniformly dusty in appearance.
  • vs. Star Rosette (Physcia stellaris)
    • Star Rosette has white-rimmed apothecia.
    • Powdery Shield generally lacks apothecia and appears softer.
  • vs. Common Greenshield (Flavoparmelia caperata)
    • Greenshield is large and leafy with wide lobes.
    • Powdery Shield is tiny, delicate, and fine-textured.
  • vs. Hammered Shield (Parmeliopsis ambigua)
    • Hammered Shield has a “hammered metal” surface with stippling.
    • Powdery Shield has a smoother, more powdery texture.

Habitat

Powdery Shield grows on:

  • hardwood bark (maple, elm, ash, oak)
  • twigs and young branches
  • old fence rails and posts
  • occasionally on weathered outdoor wood

It prefers open or lightly shaded habitats where bark dries intermittently and receives scattered sunlight.
Its sensitivity to sulfur and nitrogen pollution makes it a valuable indicator of clean air.

Photographer’s Perspective

Powdery Shield’s subtlety is its beauty —
a lichen that rarely demands attention yet rewards close examination.
Its matte surface plays softly with winter light, especially when paired with brighter species like Candleflame.
In mixed communities, its dusty rosettes often provide the cool counterbalance to warmer, more vibrant neighbors.

Related Species

  • Candleflame Lichen (Candelaria concolor)
  • Common Greenshield (Flavoparmelia caperata)
  • Star Rosette (Physcia stellaris)
  • Common Sunburst (Xanthoria parietina)
